Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Race, Entrepreneurship, and Urban Revitalization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The past two decades have seen a period of urban transformation guided by a reliance on gentrification to improve cities, which has both costs and benefits. However, few studies examine the ways that local small businesses fare in the context of gentrification. This project investigates how gentrification-based redevelopment impacts urban black-owned businesses compared to urban white-owned businesses. Considering that neighborhood conditions, especially in cities, are shaped by the commercial enterprises that serve the community, understanding the varied experiences of black business-ownership and white business-ownership during redevelopment will inform public discourse regarding wealth attainment, employment, and neighborhood conditions. Furthermore, this project will have practical implications for public policies aiming to encourage more inclusive redevelopment programs and to develop infrastructure that will more effectively support commercial and residential retention.

This project employs a mixed-method design to address three research questions. First, the U.S. Census: Survey of Business Owners (SBO) is used to answer questions regarding the spatial and temporal trends in black and white business development in Detroit, Michigan between 1997 and 2012. These data will be used to illustrate and compare businesses in size, number of paid employees, and receipts. Second, archival material from two prominent Detroit newspapers published between 1997 and 2018 are used to examine how the incorporation of black-owned businesses in media accounts of redevelopment compare to the incorporation of white-owned businesses. Finally, through in-depth, qualitative interviews and ethnographic observation, this project investigates how black and white business-owners differ in the ways they perceive and negotiate access to and ownership over local business resources, such as capital investment, consumers, and networks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The rapid expansion of gentrification as an urban redevelopment strategy in the U.S. has led to greater focus on its costs and benefits, especially for poor and minority residents. However, relatively few studies have examined how gentrification impacts local businesses. This research examined how revitalization strategies impact black-owned businesses compared to white-owned businesses. I used the U.S. Census Survey of Business Owners, archival data, interviews, and ethnographic observations to determine (1) how trends in black business development compare to white business development; (2) how the incorporation of black businesses into the visual and discursive accounts of revitalization efforts compare to the incorporation of white businesses; and, (3) how the ways that black business owners characterize the experience of business ownership and operation in the context of urban redevelopment differ from those of white business owners.

Findings reveal that contemporary patterns of urban revitalization, particularly gentrification-driven redevelopment, exacerbates long-standing racial disparities in business ownership. While rates of rates of black business ownership have risen in the past two decades, black business continue to generate lower sales and receipts, hire fewer employees, and have smaller payrolls than their white counterparts, even in cities where blacks make up the majority of the population. Moreover, as cities increasingly emphasize the production of upscale retail, restaurant, and entertainment spaces in an effort to attract more affluent residents to urban neighborhoods, black businesses and black neighborhoods are marginalized. Black entrepreneurs are at an extreme disadvantage in procuring the financial capital necessary to start, operate, and grow a business. In the context of rising rents, greater competition, and increased oversight brought on by revitalization efforts, I find that the challenge of business ownership is heighted for black entrepreneurs.

These findings, which will be submitted to academic press publishers in 2020, contribute new insights into the social, cultural, political, and economic dynamics of urban revitalization in U.S. cities. Previous urban scholarship has focused almost exclusively on the material or cultural impacts of redevelopment on residential outcomes. This research extends that scholarship by examining the interplay between the material and cultural impacts of gentrification on small businesses. Whereas previous studies have examined residential turnover and displacement, this research attempts to address gaps in our understanding of how gentrification impacts neighborhood business retention or disruption. This study illuminates specific material and cultural mechanisms that perpetuate the unequal distribution of resources in urban space. Examining varied experiences of black business ownership and white business ownership in the context of urban transformation is of particular importance to scholarship as it shines a light on how advantage is conferred to some neighborhoods and withheld from others.

In terms of broader impact, this project has the potential to inform policies and practices that can improve outcomes of urban African American communities. Understanding the varied experiences of black business owners and white business owners in the contemporary urban context helps to enhance our understanding of racial disparities in entrepreneurship. These insights shed light on the persistence of racial disparities in the nature and quality of wealth attainment, employment, and neighborhood conditions. Finally, this research has the potential to inform debates surrounding urban policy?s reliance on market-based interventions to revitalize urban communities. As this research demonstrates how urban growth policies and processes can perpetuate inequality through implicit and explicit barriers, policy makers can use this information to construct more equitable redevelopment strategies.
